1. Enable airplane mode outside this app
2. Enable airplane mode inside this app with the checkbox
3. Long-click "Save ON Length" for 0 ms ON length
4. Check "Steady ON length"
5. Get frequency close with sliders
6. Press "Hide" button
7. Fine tune frequency with volume keys
8. Adjust the settings above
9. Lock phone and wait for system to settle

Welcome to the Strobily turntable calibrator. This is for calibrating your record-playing turntables. To begin, you\'ll need to attach a pattern to your turntable. A good start would be to search \"strobe calibrate turntable\" on Google.
Select the highest frequency that is green, then adjust your turntable until the pattern appears to stop moving.
Welcome to the Strobily widget creator. This page allows you to set any of your saved patterns as widgets that you can click on your homescreen. \n\nTo begin, select a pattern:

This part of the app uses sound to identify the frequency of a spinning object. To use it, find a spinning object that is making a sound and press one of the four buttons to take a sound sample. 

When the results appear, the first number is the frequency that was identified and the other buttons represent fractions of that frequency. The greener a button is, the stronger that frequency was identified. (However if they're all green, most likely no match was found.) Normal-colored buttons did not rank in the top 5. 

If your spinning object is not making a sound, you may have to intervene. An example would be sticking a playing card into a fan in order to make a repeating sound. 

The Strobe Frequency Offset allows you to flash at a slightly different frequency than your spinning object such that it will appear to slowly spin. This value is only applied when you select a frequency (it doesn't affect detection).

This graph show what the app was doing during the past 100 flashes. The x-axis width is set so that it exactly matches the frequency of the strobe. 

Think of each row as 1 bar of music. The LED needs to turn fully-on and fully-off within 1 bar to keep up with the tempo. If the tempo is too fast, the LED falls behind and isn't able to turn on and off before the next row starts. 

Perfect performance will be a white vertical line. Diagonal lines mean it's not keeping up.
